ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

OLDER HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT BOARD ESTATES
(Stepping up of Main Upgrading Programme)


    1. Dr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether the Main Upgrading Programme can be further stepped up in the older Housing and Development Board estates.

Column: 1426



     The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Hng Kiang): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Main Upgrading Programme has been gradually stepped up from six to 10 precincts a year. From 1995 onwards, it will be further stepped up to 15 precincts per year.

    Too rapid an acceleration of the programme may result in the overheating of the building industry which, in turn, may lead to increased construction costs and lower standards of workmanship. Whether the programme can be further stepped up will thus depend on the industry's capacity to absorb the added projects.

    It will also depend on whether the Government is able to generate s ufficient budgetary surplus to fund the programme. The Government will also have to consider how it apportions its budget for upgrading HDB flats vis-a-vis other public programmes like MRT lines, education and health.

     Dr S. Vasoo (Tanjong Pagar GRC): In spite of the Minister's answer, are there any concrete plans for the older housing estates?

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Sir, at 15 precincts per year the budget for the Main Upgrading Programme is almost $1 billion. As Members of the House will know, the Government has several very large projects in the pipeline and we have to ensure that the budget is fairly and rationally apportioned among the various projects. As Members know, the North-East sector MRT line will cost us $5 billion. The Public Works Department is also looking at the underground road system which may eventually cost us $4.8 billion. Last year, we set aside $1 billion for the Edusave fund. As Members also know, we have three big hospitals under construction: the Kandang Kerbau Hospital has a budget of $300 million; the Eastern General Hospital also has a budget of $300 million; and the Tan Tock Seng Hospital has a budget of $400 million, totalling another $1 billion. So there are several big projects and the HDB's upgrading programme, with a budget of $1 billion, is already a very large programme.

Column: 1427

BUS SHELTERS NEAR NEW LINKWAYS
(Upgrading)


    2. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for National Development whether there are any plans to upgrade the bus shelters in areas where new linkways have been built.

     Mr Lim Hng Kiang: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Public Works Department (PWD) has no plans to upgrade the bus shelters in areas where new linkways have been built by the Citizens' Consultative Committees (CCCs) or Town Councils using Community Improvement Projects Committee (CIPC) funds.

    The CCCs can apply for CIPC funding for the upgrading of such bus shelters if they meet three conditions:

    (1) the bus shelters must be older than 10 years. This is to ensure that public funds are not wasted through the replacement of existing shelters which are still in good condition;

    (2) the existing bus shelter does not blend well with the covered linkway; and

    (3) they have obtained approval from the PWD and other technical departments for the design of the shelters.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT FUND SCHEME FOR FOREIGN WORKERS
(Withdrawal of savings before age 55)


    3. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Labour, after 1998, or when the tax exempt Central Provident Fund (CPF) contribution scheme for foreign workers ceases (whichever is the later), whether he will allow the foreign workers to withdraw their savings from their CPF account at that time without waiting till the age of 55.

     The Minister for Labour (Dr Lee Boon Yang): Mr Speaker, Sir, existing CPF withdrawal rules allow foreign workers, except West Malaysians, to withdraw their CPF savings when they leave Singapore at the end of their employment. As for West Malaysians, they are allowed to withdraw their CPF savings at age 50, if they have not worked in Singapore for the two years prior to their application for withdrawal.

Column: 1428

Hence, foreigners, unlike Singaporean workers, need not wait till the age of 55 to withdraw their CPF savings.

    The Ministry has no intention to change these withdrawal rules for foreigners with CPF savings who will be exempted from mandatory CPF contributions on or before 31st December 1998. The exemption from CPF contributions does not affect savings already accumulated in their CPF accounts.

Column: 1428

MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT
(Ex-gratia payment)


    4. Mr Ling How Doong asked the Prime Minister if he will name the 47 Members of Parliament who will receive the ex-gratia payment and how many of them were Cabinet Ministers, Ministers of State, Parliamentary Secretaries and Political Secretaries.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Wong Kan Seng) (for the Prime Minister): Sir, the 47 retired Members of Parliament who will receive the "ex-gratia" payment are listed in the Annex (Cols. 1489 - 1492) which I have asked the Clerk of Parliament to distribute.
Annex - MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT WHO WILL RECEIVE THE "EX-GRATIA" PAYMENT (Cols. 1489 - 1492)


    Of these, 20 will also receive an "ex-gratia" for their office-holder service. Ten of them last held appointment as Ministers or Deputy Prime Ministers, four as Ministers of State and six as Parliamentary Secretaries.

    There are some other former MPs who have held office but will not receive the office-holder "ex-gratia" because they did not have the adequate service to qualify for an office-holder pension.

     Mr Ling How Doong (Bukit Gombak): Sir, would the Minister tell the House the amount of gratuity and monthly pension that they received?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng: Sir, the pension received by the former Ministers and MPs is paid according to a formula under the Parliamentary Pensions Act. I do not have the information here but if the Member is interested he can work it out from the service that the Member has done and find out how much a person would have got in terms of gratuity or pension.

Column: 1429

RETIRED CIVIL SERVANTS
(Ex-gratia payment)


    5. Mr Ling How Doong asked the Prime Minister, as Members of Parliament who retired before 31st December 1992 will receive the ex-gratia payment, whether the Government will consider the same for civil servants who retired before 31st December 1992 instead of 1st January 1982 and, if so, how many more retired civil servants will benefit from the scheme and the additional amount involved.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng (for the Prime Minister): Sir, the answer to the first part of the Question is "no". The civil servants will not be considered for the same kind of ex-gratia payment when they retired before 31st December 1992 instead of 1st January 1982.

    The reason is that it is not appropriate to compare Members of Parliament with civil servants. The retired civil servants' contribution to the political destiny of Singapore, while important, was not equal to that of the retired MPs. They did not face the same risk to their lives and limbs as the MPs who stood for and won their elections in the turbulent period from 1959 to 1965. Furthermore, pensionable civil servants have secure tenure whereas the MPs' tenure is uncertain. They may or may not be re-elected. Moreover, those civil servants who retired after 1st January 1982 would have received a higher pension because the NWC payments after this date, till 1993, were made pensionable. From 1993, NWC adjustments as well as salary revisions were made non-pensionable.

    Although MPs who retired before 31st December 1992 will receive the "ex-gratia" payment, the cut-off date for computing their reckonable service for the "ex-gratia" payment is 31st March 1989, and not 31st December 1992. This is because the MP's allowance was significantly revised after 31st March 1989 and the service rendered after this date had been adequately recognised.

Column: 1430

NEW NTUC COMFORT TAXIS
(Radio despatch system)


    6. Encik Harun bin A. Ghani asked the Minister for Communications why the new NTUC Comfort taxis are not equipped with the radio despatch system.

     The Minister for Communications (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry encourages all taxi companies to fully equip their fleet with radio despatch systems. This will enable the companies to utilise and deploy their taxi fleet more efficiently to meet commuter demand. It will also cut down the need for taxi drivers to drive around looking for passengers, thereby reducing unnecessary mileage and congestion on the road.

    All taxi companies, including Comfort, are actively looking into upgrading or replacing their present system to a new Automated Taxi Despatch System using Global Positioning Satellites. I am told that Comfort's present despatch system is only able to serve about 3,000 taxis. Increasing the number of taxis on its present network will adversely affect the system's efficiency. When Comfort commissions its new Automated Despatch System, it will be able to equip its new taxis with the despatch system. It can also expand its despatch network to its entire fleet of 10,000 taxis.

Column: 1430

KEPPEL SHIPYARD
(Investigation into bribe to Exxon employee)


    7. Mr Ling How Doong asked the Prime Minister whether he is aware that a Government-linked-company, Keppel Shipyard, offered a bribe of $144,000 to an employee of Exxon and whether he will consider ordering an investigation with a view to prosecuting the wrongdoers.

     Mr Wong Kan Seng (for the Prime Minister): The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau has informed the Prime Minister that it has initiated action on the matter. It would be highly prejudicial to the investigations to disclose any further details.

Column: 1431

NORTH-EAST MRT LINE
(Feasibility study report)


    8. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Minister for Communications whether the report on the feasibility study of the North-East MRT line has been completed and, if so, whether that MRT line shall pass through the Potong Pasir Constituency.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, MINCOM announced on 14th July 1995 that the Mass Rapid Transit Corporation (MRTC) had completed its feasibility study on the North-East line.

    The MRTC study is based on a 20-km line running from World Trade Centre in the south to Punggol in the north. The exact route alignment, the number and location of the stations have not been finalised. These will be settled after further discussion with the land-use planning and other relevant agencies.

    Mr Chiam asked whether the line would pass through Potong Pasir constituency. The answer is "yes". But the location of the station has yet to be finalised. MRTC's consultants who carried out the North-East line feasibility study had analysed various possibilities for station locations. On the possibility of having a station at Potong Pasir, this is what they had to say:

    `Potong Pasir is the weakest station on the North-East line. Although there are plans to develop the area near the proposed station, it will improve the viability of North-East line, if Potong Pasir station were deferred (to save) about $1 million per year.'

    Straits Times reported Mr Chiam on 27th July 1995 as saying apropos the North-East line that "Any decision has to be made rationally." He is right. It is a $5 billion decision which must be carefully weighed. In deciding when to proceed with the construction of the North-East line and the exact alignment and station locations, the Government will take a broad view and consider other benefits that can be derived from this investment, such as reduced travel time, and an expanded and improved public transport system. The House can expect a firm decision by the end of this year.

Column: 1432



     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Sir, I thank the Minister for telling the House that the North-East line shall be passing through Potong Pasir. Can the Members view the report of the feasibility study?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, the feasibility study is a technical study and it contains confidential information, eg, information concerning possible alignment of the routes, locations and so on. Under the circumstances, such information at this stage would still be considered confidential and I am not prepared to release the report at this stage.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Cheng San GRC): Sir, as the MINCOM's statement has indicated that $5 billion is a huge sum to spend on the North-East line, may I ask the Minister whether he would consider a much cheaper option by having a fish-hook loop, branching off from Yio Chu Kang station of the North-South line to pass through Jalan Kayu, Kangkar, Punggol and Serangoon New Towns? And if it stops there, many of the stations would be above ground. I believe it would be much cheaper. Unfortunately, it will also have the unintended effect of bypassing Potong Pasir.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, I have not actually thought about that particular alignment. But since the Member has raised the possibility, I think it will be an interesting exercise to see whether we can still serve the residents in that area and save the Government some money as well.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, why is the proposed station at Potong Pasir considered a "weak" station?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, at each proposed station, the consultants have taken into account the ridership; in other words, they have taken into account the catchment area around that particular station, compared with the actual cost of running and operating that station. In that sense, I believe the consultants have come to the conclusion that of all the proposed stations that they have studied, the Potong Pasir station, taking the ridership from that particular station and taking the cost of operating that station, is the weakest station on that line.

Column: 1433



     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, how long does the Minister expect to wait before the station can become a "strong" station so that it can be built?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, at this stage, it is difficult for me to answer that question. But based on the current plans for redevelopment of that whole corridor - and this is what the study is currently based on - the ridership around that station is still not sufficient or not strong enough to warrant it being built, that is, if the consultants' recommendation is to be accepted.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Tampines GRC): Sir, to put the matter in perspective, will the Minister tell us how does this $5 billion compare to the total cost of building the present MRT line, and how many people will benefit from this North-East line?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as the MINCOM's press release pointed out, the cost of $5 billion for the North-East line is equivalent to the total cost of building the North-South-East-West line. The North-South-East-West line today carries something like 700,000-800,000 passengers per day. As a comparison, the North-East line is expected to carry something like 200,000-250,000 passengers. The cost is the same. The ridership is roughly one-third.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, what is the consultants' opinion about the strength of the proposed station at Hougang Central, in terms of ridership and other factors?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: It is not the weakest, Sir.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, in fact, there are two pieces of vacant land at Potong Pasir Constituency adjacent to Upper Sera ngoon Road. They are in fact ready for the construction of a station. Does the Minister not think that it would be more feasible to build the station once the line is built rather than to wait later on when prices would have gone up?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, I am familiar with the two pieces of land that the Member is talking about. But I think he would also realise that building a station does not depend on whether there are empty

Column: 1434

pieces of land. It also depends on many other factors, including, as I said, the catchment area around that proposed station. In any case, if he looks at the area around his constituency, he will notice that there are many other empty pieces of land which are not within the Potong Pasir constituency.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Sir, would the North-East line follow approximately the Serangoon/Upper Serangoon Roads all the way to Punggol?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as I said, at this stage, it will be premature for me to give too much details about the proposed alignment of the North-East line, for reasons which I think the Member himself is aware. In other words, there are certain confidential information pertaining to the alignment and the location which must necessarily be kept under wraps at this stage. But he asked a specific question and I attempted to answer that question to his satisfaction.

     Mr Goh Choon Kang (Braddell Heights): Sir, can I ask the Minister how is Braddell Heights Constituency compared to Hougang and Potong Pasir?

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: It is quite strong!

LAND BRIDGE LINK BETWEEN PENANG AND SONGKHLA
(Effect on Singapore)


    9. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Communications if he will give an assessment on whether the proposed land bridge link between Penang in Malaysia and Songkhla in Thailand will affect Singapore.

     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Mr Speaker, Sir, Malaysia's proposal for a Penang-Songkhla land bridge was raised within the Indonesia-Malaysia-Thailand Growth Triangle (IMT-GT) economic cooperation framework. We do not know at this stage the details of the project proposal. However, it is clear that the envisoned project is a massive one, and will involve substantial investments in roads, pipelines and port infrastructure. The financial viability of the project will also depend on how competitive the costs of unloading,

Column: 1435

transportation and re-loading of cargo are, in relation to the existing alternatives. As the preliminary feasibility study into the project has not yet been completed, it is too early for me to comment on the project's impact on Singapore.

    The land bridge project is part of a wider trend in the Asia-Pacific. With rapid economic growth, the region will continue to experience an increase in container traffic. The volume of containers handled by PSA alone has been rising at an average rate of 21% per annum between 1984 and 1994. Emerging ports in China, Indochina and as far away as the Middle East are understandably eager to compete and tap a share of the region's dynamic growth.

    PSA is well-positioned to grow with the region. Singapore's strength is our ability to provide the shipping community a total service capability at competitive prices. This is due to our excellent infrastructure and active investment in anticipation of future infrastructure needs, as well as our ongoing efforts to maintain high productivity growth rates.

    The completion of Brani Terminal, and the upgrading of Tanjong Pagar and Keppel Terminals, will meet PSA's capacity requirements fully by 1997. PSA has already begun to develop a new container terminal at Pasir Panjang which will commence operations by 1998, and eventually double PSA's total handling capacity from 16 million TEUs (Twenty-Foot Equivalent Units) to about 34 million TEUs by the year 2007.

    PSA is also striving to keep our international port productivity ranking at number one through skills upgrading programmes and by increasing port automation. For example, state-of-the-art equipment like Overhead Bridge Cranes and Automated Guided Vehicles are being tested for the new terminal to enhance PSA's technological edge and operational efficiency. By adopting a farsighted and proactive approach, PSA is poised and ready to meet the challenges of tomorrow.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, if the land bridge project should eventually proceed, would the Minister be able to assess how much it would affect the port of Singapore?

Column: 1436



     Mr Mah Bow Tan: Sir, as I indicated in my answer, it is very difficult for us at this stage to give an answer to that question. Partly, it is dependent on how much the actual cost will be incurred by operators using that route, and how much will be the comparable cost using the port of Singapore. Secondly, the pie will grow. The region is growing and it is quite possible that eventually when the land bridge is built, if it is found feasible, it is quite possible that there will be sufficient business for both the land bridge as well as the port of Singapore. But all these are hypothetical answers because, as I said, we would have to, first of all, determine whether that particular project is feasible and what are the details involved in building such a massive infrastructure.

CLASS SIZE IN SCHOOLS
(Reduction)


    10. Mr Low Thia Khiang asked the Minister for Education whether he will consider reducing class size in schools in view of a recent study by Tennessee State University in the United States which concluded that students in small classes outperform those in large classes.

     The Minister for Education (Mr Lee Yock Suan): Mr Speaker, Sir, research evidence on the effect of reducing class size on pupil achievement is inconclusive. While studies such as the one conducted in Tennessee favour small classes, there are other studies which suggest that small class sizes do not result in any gain in pupil achievement.

    Better instructional methods and the use of information technology may well result in larger achievement gains. This is an important consideration in view of our limited manpower and land. A reduction in class size will entail the recruitment of significantly more teachers and the building of more schools. We should not commit such scarce resources unless there is strong and conclusive evidence that smaller classes do in fact bring about significant gains in pupil achievement.

    Schools in Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong generally have large classes of 40 or more pupils per class. Yet

Column: 1437

they have achieved better academic performance than western countries with much smaller class sizes. In Singapore, our better and more popular schools tend to have larger class sizes than schools with declining enrolment. One reason for the smaller class sizes in western countries is their reluctance or inability to close schools which have declining enrolment.

     Mr Low Thia Khiang: Sir, in the March 1992 Budget debate, I raised the same issue and in his answer, the Minister referred to the US computer studies of educational achievement. He said that class size did not matter. Whereas this study shows that smaller classes will help students to perform better. The Minister says that it is inconclusive. EMPRESS PLACE MUSEUM


    7. Dr Kanwaljit Soin asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what were the reasons for the closure of the Empress Place Museum; (b) what was the total amount spent on the whole venture; and (c) what lessons were learnt from the experience.

     Mr Yeo Cheow Tong:

    (a) Reasons for the closure

    In February 1986, the PRC and Singapore Governments agreed to stage in Singapore a series of 5 exhibitions on PRC historical and cultural relics. This was part of our bilateral co-operation in tourism. As part of the agreement, Singapore Government formed a company, the Historical and Cultural Exhibitions Pte Ltd, to stage the exhibitions. The Empress Place Building was selected as the venue for the exhibitions. The first exhibition started in April 89 and the fifth, and last in the series, was completed on 30th April 95.

    Government decided to close the Empress Place Museum from 1st May 1995 as (a) the 5 exhibitions under the bilateral agreement have been staged; and (b) the Historical and Cultural Exhibitions Pte Ltd, which operated the Empress Place Building, was not financially viable despite the support of the travel industry.

    (b) Total amount spent

    The entire venture cost $31 million, most of which were spent renovating the building and offsetting the operating losses.

    (c) Lessons learnt

    The Empress Place Building was opened in 1989 for a specific objective, namely, to stage the 5 exhibitions on PRC historical and cultural relics as part of our bilateral co-operation in tourism. It has achieved this objective. The 5 world-class exhibitions have fostered a better understanding of Chinese history and culture among the more than 1.5 million Singaporeans and tourists who visited them.

    The intention when the Historical and Cultural Exhibitions Pte Ltd was set up was for the company to operate on a commercial basis with no Government subsidy. Despite the company_s marketing and publicity efforts, and the quality of its exhibits, the exhibitions did not draw in the crowds. This was especially so among locals, whose visitorship dropped from 218,000 when the exhibition first opened in 1989 to less than 40,000 a year during the last 4 years. This reflects the need for continued arts promotion among Singaporeans by the Government and interested cultural groups.
